NEW YORK

FRIDAY, JULY 1, 1857.

We are glad to observe that during the recent North West Termination are to be visited by members of the Cabinet Ministers. Sir John Macdonald is expected to visit the North West at Red River Springs. The Hon. Mr. Thompson, as it is reported, will visit Manitoba and the Territories and Hon. Mr. White will also visit the Far West. It is said that Mr. Thompson is among others on the tour. Here he will be subject to keen criticism. However, it is anticipated that nothing but honest impressions will be given to the public by him.

The continued interest Ministers are taking in the North West, as evidenced by their personal visits year by year, is highly commendable. It demonstrates their sense of responsibility and its importance, which is emphasized in its most reliable form and must have more forceful and lasting influence than the Ministerial visits that have been made in the past. It shows that the Government has not forgotten its obligations and that departmental reports or ministerial visits are no longer acceptable.

COMMUNICATIONS.

We observe Sir William recently introduced a bill into the House proposing to send land surveyors to examine the boundaries between the Assiniboia, Long Lake, and Saskatchewan, when no provisions exist to cover the North Branch at the point where the first recorded boundary line was drawn through Assiniboia. We believe that such a proposal would be well received by the Government, who have been engaged in similar surveys for many years.

SEED GRAIN.

I understand that Mr. McTaggart has sent his seed grain to the Government, and I am sure that it will be received with great satisfaction. It is a fact that the Government has been engaged in seed grain surveys for many years.

FRIDAY, JULY 1, 1867.

ST. ANNY'S CONVENT

Second Annual Distribution of Prizes.

On Monday, the 25th, the second annual distribution of prizes in the above institution was held in the school-room, under the charge of Miss Wilson.

Miss Wilson has extended their instructions not only to the parents and guardians of the children, but also to the teachers and pupils themselves; and there was a large turn out of pupils from the town and surrounding district. The children, both boys and girls, were very attentive and excellent scholars. Miss Wilson has been very successful in her endeavours to improve the moral and intellectual condition of the children. She has been very attentive to the young lady pupils. At the conclusion of the proceedings, Miss Wilson spoke to the pupils, and after the interesting pre- sentation of prizes had been concluded, Mr. Clarke spoke to the pupils.

PICNIC

On Monday the annual picnic of Lindsay School was held with great success. The day was fine and cool, with a slight shower, but this can scarcely be said to have at all dampened the spirits of the assembled company, extracted from the pleasantness of the meeting. Owing to the high place which Mr. Atwater holds in the esteem not only of scholars but pupils alike, there was a large turn out of the population of Lindsay and to the eye of an astron- omer the scene presented itself as one observing the affectionate deference of old and young towards the teacher who had been so kind as to give all in return. The large company included guests from neighboring parishes and friends from Prince Albert holding a comfort and companionship. Mr. Atwater and parishioners were indefatigably active.

In preparation for the meeting a large and lofty pine tree bower had been constructed adjoining the school house, where the children could sit comfortably under the boughs, and a part of the area en- closed was comfortably floored where the band could be placed and where afterwards an "evolution" of dance was indulged in.

A special feature in the programme was a tall flag staff on which in honor of the jubilee of our Gracious Queen that ed an elegant union jack, visited from afar by the Queen herself. When the Duke of Prince Albert paid a flying visit to the school on a musical mission and put the children through their paces in a most engaging style, and while the company assembled as assembling Mr. T. Adams played a selection of tunes on the harmonium which were most appreciated.

About mid-day the serious business of lunchroom commenced and was promptly concluded by all present. The children first, visitors next and the general com- pany afterwards. The elders then in groups visited the grounds and took in the prospects of the crops and the affairs of the nation generally, while the young- sters played games and games and games until at a given signal the whole company assembled in and about the bower. The children sang, under the able leadership of Mr. Adams, sang with fine effect the Queen's Anthem in which the whole assembly joined.

Mr. Atwater then addressed the assem- bly a few well chosen remarks of a generous character. He spoke of the obligations which existed between the inhabitants of Lindsay and himself, engaging the children for their future and assuring them that they should be well educated and the children for their attentiveness and attention which he highly commended and encouraged in him as their teacher. He also mentioned the great obligations they were under to treat their parents with respect in school affairs and finally, referring to the auspicious date on which their picnic was being held, he referred to the many reasons which existed for a warm and heartfelt celebration of the Queen's Jubilee. These remarks were received with warm applause by the large audience.

Mr. James Flett, incumbent of the parish then delivered a short address ad- mirably suited to the occasion. The Canon, from his wide experience, fully concurred in the charitable intentions as- sociated with the kindly and harmonious cha- racter of the people of Lindsay. His interest in the welfare of the school was a source of great pleasure to him and, he sincerely hoped, of some profit to them. He also spoke of the importance of the school and, after some highly apposite historical allusions, forcibly endorsed the chair- man's sentiments regarding the aims and ambitions. Having made a special reference to the day's proceedings, the Canon concluded with an interesting address upon the importance with which the spiritual and temporal welfare of the People.

Capt. Craig was next called upon. He spoke of the importance of harmony every where, especially in small communities and in the various parts of the country on the state of matters among them as disclosed in the remarks of the previous speaker. He congratulated the school on possessing a prominent head like Mr. Atwater, spoke to the children on the importance of education and cre- ated enthusiasm in taking advantage of the unusual opportunity of acquiring learn- ing that was now within their reach. Having spoken briefly to the gathering, he made way for Mr. Charles Adams, who, good naturedly without the damping effects of a heavy thunder shower, spoke briefly and pleasantly on the topics of the day and, in connection with the reign of George the Third, one of the few sovereigns who knew how to make a public speech. Mr. Andrew Spencer then took the floor and spoke in a kindly style appro- priately wound up this part of the programme by a very general observation or two on the subject of the weather, his views with the sentiments that had fallen from previous speakers and his good wishes to all present.

Cheers were then given for the teacher, the trustees, the guests, Mrs. Canon Flett who had presided over the children in such a agreeable way, the teachers, special cheers for the Queen were called for first, Crees, then in English and given by all the children present. After the order of the evening was at its stage your correspondent must call a halt. He endeavored to keep the children quiet kept it up till the small hours, but this was long after he had sought the arms of "Tired nature's sweet remedy, balmy rest."

OUR DAIRY BREAD

How important our present happiness and future welfare unbalances the bless- ing of good health. Under a suitable condi- tion, it is easy to repair the damage. Notwithstanding these facts, thousands of persons daily jeopardize not only their own lives, but the lives and the health and lives of others, by using articles in the preparation of their food which are injurious to the body which they know nothing. Perhaps few cents may have been saved, or it may have been thought that the article was more cheaply used, and the housekeeper takes the re- sponsibility and possibly will never know the mischief that has been wrought. TOWN COUNCIL

An adjourned meeting of the Council was held on Monday evening last.

Present Coms. Bain, Agnew and Stewart, with Mayor MacArthur in the chair.

The usual routine of reading minutes was gone through, when a

COMMUNICATION

was read from V. Maclean on behalf of the South Eastern Rail Road Company of Jacob referring to right of way across river lot 52.

AN ANNOUNCEMENT

was received from M. McLaughlin for removing matter, 817, referred to Finance Committee.

Com. Bain moved a resolution adopted by a law to pro- vide for good order and the suppression of vice and immorality.

Com. Stewart introduced a by law for the appointment of a special police officer.

SPECIAL COUNCIL REPORT

Com. Bain had the contract for holders to W. J. Carter and the rest of the ap- pliances to Mr. Farquhar.

On motion of Coms. Agnew and Bain, the other made by the Mayor, the report was accepted and the Town Solicitor instructed to see the

Com. Bain reported that he had ad- vertised for tenders for water tanks.

Com. Stewart gave notice that he would move a by law to close streets before lot 398.

Moved by Com. Bain, seconded by Com. Stewart that in view of the recent fire at the Transporation Company building a loading and ware- house, all taxes against their Company be assessed.

The by law for licensing livery stables, etc., was read a third time and passed, and ordered to be signed, sealed and announced.

The by law for appointing a License Inspector was passed, and ordered to be signed, sealed and announced.

The Council adjourned.
